thread.title: 9 ways we could name Reno's new soccer team
thread.title_full: 9 ways we could name Reno's new soccer team

title: 9 ways we could name Reno's new soccer team
text:
9 ways we could name Reno's new soccer team Ways we can name Reno's new soccer team The owners of Reno's professional soccer team, set to begin play in 2017, are asking for the public's help in naming the team. Dusting off the name of a defunct team isn't a terrible idea, and we have a few to choose from: Reno Soccer Club (1970s); Reno Rattlers (1994-98); Northern Nevada Aces (2001-04). But where's the fun in that? If we're going with a brand-new name, here are our suggestions. Sponsored by RGJ file Civic nicknames 
The best part about civic nicknames is feeling like an insider. "Our nickname is because we're the City of Roses ... you wouldn't get that as a non-Portlandian." 
Examples: Chicago Fire (Chicago, IL); Portland Thorns (Portland, OR) 
Our suggestion: B.L.C.F.C. Getty Images Neighborhoods and suburbs 
For the sake of civic pride, it's ideal to get your hometown somewhere in your name. If you're in a city like London (40-plus teams), it starts to make sense to name teams after neighborhoods instead. 
Examples: Rosenborg BK (Trondheim, Norway); Aston Villa (Birmingham, England) 
Our suggestion: Riverwalk F.C.; Old Brewery District F.C. Lisa J. Tolda/RGJ Years 
Years figure prominently in soccer team names throughout Europe, though they're generally drawn from the team's founding year (and let's face it, it's going to take decades for "Reno 2017" to sound cool.) Maybe we pick another significant year? 
Examples: Vancouver 86ers (Vancouver, B.C.); 1860 München (Munich, Germany) 
Our suggestions: City of Reno 1868; Nevada 1864 Plants 
If you're looking to emphasize the action and excitement of soccer, nothing says "dynamic" quite like plants. 
Examples: Linlithgow Rose F.C. (West Lothian, Scotland); Accra Hearts of Oak S.C. (Accra, Ghana) 
Our suggestion: Nevada Sagebrush Andy Barron/RGJ Authority 
The Spanish royal family has bestowed the word "real" ("royal") on several soccer teams, and a handful of teams not living under monarchies use it as well (though we're not quite sure why). Perhaps we can Americanize that trend a bit. 
Examples: Real Madrid (Madrid, Spain); Real Garcilaso (Cusco, Peru); Real Salt Lake (Sandy, UT) 
Our suggestion: Schieve Mayoral F.C. Thinkstock Youth 
Why not name your team after young people? Anyone who has the energy to run around for 45 solid minutes surely has some youthful energy. 
Examples: Juventus F.C. (Turin, Italy); Boca Juniors (Buenos Aires, Argentina); Wexford Youths (Crossabeg, Ireland) 
Our suggestion: Reno Millennials F.C. Marilyn Newton/RGJ Unity 
If the soccer team is going to be a success, it will need to draw from throughout the region, not just within the Reno city limits. And everyone likes to be included. 
Examples: D.C. United (Washington, D.C.); Manchester United (Manchester, England); Unión de Santa Fe (Santa Fe, Argentina) 
Our suggestions: Sierra United; Unity 775 Lisa J. Tolda/RGJ Legendary figures 
Real, mythical, or somewhere in between - the best way to honor our regional legends might be to have a bunch of grown men wear their names and run around after a ball for 90 minutes every weekend. 
Examples: Ulisses F.C. (Yerevan, Armenia); SS Jeanne d'Arc (Le Port, Réunion Island) 
Our suggestions: "Old Virginny" Finney United RGJ file The way we name all our other teams 
Collective noun team names may be the standard in other American sports, but they're definitely in the minority among soccer teams. 
Examples: Colorado Rapids (Commerce City, CO); Tiburones Rojos (Red Sharks) de Veracruz (Veracruz, Mexico) 
Our suggestion: Reno Silver Sox USL Reno Brett McGinness , bmcginness@rgj.com 10:10 a.m. PDT October 1, 2015 Aces Ballpark will be home to a pro soccer team. (Photo: USL) 312 CONNECT 10 TWEET LINKEDIN 2 COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
The owners of Reno's professional soccer team, set to begin play in 2017, are asking for the public's help in naming the team. Dusting off the name of a defunct team isn’t a terrible idea, and we have a few to choose from: Reno Soccer Club (1970s); Reno Rattlers (1994-98); Northern Nevada Aces (2001-04). But where's the fun in that? If we're going with a brand-new name, here are our suggestions. You can submit your own name ideas at the USL Reno website. 
Civic nicknames 
The best part about civic nicknames is feeling like an insider. “Our nickname is because we’re the City of Roses … you wouldn’t get that as a non-Portlandian.” 
Examples: Chicago Fire (Chicago, IL); Portland Thorns (Portland, OR) 
Our suggestion: B.L.C.F.C. 
Neighborhoods and suburbs 
For the sake of civic pride, it’s ideal to get your hometown somewhere in your name. If you’re in a city like London (40-plus teams), it starts to make sense to name teams after neighborhoods instead. 
Examples: Rosenborg BK (Trondheim, Norway); Aston Villa (Birmingham, England) 
Our suggestion: Riverwalk F.C.; Old Brewery District F.C. 
Years 
Years figure prominently in soccer team names throughout Europe, though they’re generally drawn from the team’s founding year (and let’s face it, it’s going to take decades for “Reno 2017” to sound cool.) Maybe we pick another significant year? 
Examples: Vancouver 86ers (Vancouver, B.C.); 1860 München (Munich, Germany) 
Our suggestions: City of Reno 1868; Nevada 1864 
Plants 
If you’re looking to emphasize the action and excitement of soccer, nothing says “dynamic” quite like plants. 
Examples: Linlithgow Rose F.C. (West Lothian, Scotland); Accra Hearts of Oak S.C. (Accra, Ghana) 
Our suggestion: Nevada Sagebrush 
Authority 
The Spanish royal family has bestowed the word “real” (“royal”) on several soccer teams, and a handful of teams not living under monarchies use it as well (though we’re not quite sure why). Perhaps we can Americanize that trend a bit. 
Examples: Real Madrid (Madrid, Spain); Real Garcilaso (Cusco, Peru); Real Salt Lake (Sandy, UT) 
Our suggestion: Schieve Mayoral F.C. 
Youth 
Why not name your team after young people? Anyone who has the energy to run around for 45 solid minutes surely has some youthful energy. 
Examples: Juventus F.C. (Turin, Italy); Boca Juniors (Buenos Aires, Argentina); Wexford Youths (Crossabeg, Ireland) 
Our suggestion: Reno Millennials F.C. 
Unity 
If the soccer team is going to be a success, it will need to draw from throughout the region, not just within the Reno city limits. And everyone likes to be included. 
Examples: D.C. United (Washington, D.C.); Manchester United (Manchester, England); Unión de Santa Fe (Santa Fe, Argentina) 
Our suggestions: Sierra United; Unity 775 
Legendary figures 
Real, mythical, or somewhere in between – the best way to honor our regional legends might be to have a bunch of grown men wear their names and run around after a ball for 90 minutes every weekend. 
Examples: Ulisses F.C. (Yerevan, Armenia); SS Jeanne d’Arc (Le Port, Réunion Island) 
Our suggestions: “Old Virginny” Finney United 
The way we name all our other teams 
Collective noun team names may be the standard in other American sports, but they’re definitely in the minority among soccer teams. 
Examples: Colorado Rapids (Commerce City, CO); Tiburones Rojos (Red Sharks) de Veracruz (Veracruz, Mexico) 
Our suggestion: Reno Silver Sox 312 CONNECT 10 TWEET LINKEDIN 2 COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://on.rgj.com/1KOWSOp TOP VIDEOS
